Author: Steve G
Title: Mario Kart 8 DX
Body: Listen, if you've ever played a Mario Kart game then you know what you're getting into. It's Mario Kart, but it looks better than ever. It includes the 4 cups from the original game's DLC, bringing the total tracks available to 48. Nintendo is also releasing a $25 DLC that is adding an additional 48 tracks, doubling the base game's size. It's a bargain.If you enjoyed unlocking characters, I have some bad news for you--they're all unlocked from the start. The only secret character is Gold Mario, which you can get from getting a gold trophy in all the 200cc grand prix. And the 200cc is available right when you boot up the game for the first time. Kind of a letdown if you like unlockables. Kart options unlock as you collect more coins through gameplay. This maxes at 5000 coins and gives you a golden glider. If you beat the 150cc and Mirror Mode (available as soon as you boot up the game for the first time) you get a golden kart. If you beat the staff ghosts in the 150cc time trials you get golden wheels.I was skeptical at first, but listen... it's Mario Kart. It's just fun. You won't regret buying it.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Amazon Customer
Title: took hours to figure out how to do local play with 2 switch lite
Body: I talked to nintendo support for hours about this, because we bought two of the switch lite and two cartridges of this game to have the kids play it in the car on the way to school together, but couldn't figure out how to start a 2 player wireless local game.  After much trial and error, we finally found that selecting the wireless-1 player (Not 2 player), one person could create a room, and then on the 2nd switch-lite, that person also goes to wireless - 1 player (Not 2 player), and then you can see the room the other person created and join it.  So confusing!
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: swift
Title: Worth the upgrade from the wii u version
Body: As a previous owner of the wii u version of mario kart 8 who didn't have the dlc I had to upgrade to the switch version of mario kart 8.  It was on sale for the holidays so i had to get it while it was still cheap. As far as I know the dlc has an extra track and some more stuff . It's the same game as the wii u version in 1080p instead of the 720p that the wii u version had. I tested the game out with the optional hori mario kart steering wheel which I highly recommend for mario kart 8 owners. It provides a realistic arcade feel to the game instead of using a controller.  Getting back to the subject,  if you didn't have mario kart on the wii u , I highly recommend this game for switch owners
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Angela
Title: Addicted to this game
Body: I love Mario Kart in general but I’m loving it for the switch! You have so many track options and some of course are from past gaming systems which I love. Plus you have setting options that allow you to race without having to hold down a button make your car go and you have options to turn your remote into a steering wheel instead of using your toggle sticks similar to the wii. I feel that first feature is great for little kids that want to play and the second feature is good for just a more realistic feeling while driving. Overall I just love Mario Kart and feel it’s a must have for anyone that loves racing games.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Lugicorn
Title: Impossible to win 150cc
Body: So, there's a line between a challenge and the ridiculous. I have played the flower cup at 150cc 43 times with various carts and characters and I'm a fairly astute driver and still cannot win 4/4. It's totally rigged, screwing you in your final lap. What a bummer. A challenge is great, but this stopped being a challenge and crossed into the ridiculous 40 times ago. If I could return this POS game. I WOULD
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Overall, a fun game to play and it’s nostalgic since mario kart has been a game I’ve played growing up. Definitely try to get it when it goes on sale.

Author: Emma
Title: Sadly, so disappointing!
Body: I was so excited about this, I played this on my n64 and wii, but this version was really disappointing, the tracks are really short all the racers are always close together, and they seem to pick on the players collectively, not 100% sure tho. The most disappointing thing was that it advertised that it had some of the old favorite track from n64, but it was name only, the tracks were completely different and short and even the tough courses were short and easy. The hard part was every 5 seconds a racer is hitting you with something. I would also describe the tracks as over the top, just way too much happening. This was definitely targeted more for kids with ADD. I think I will return it.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Tomislav
Title: defect game + horrible customer service experience
Body: Ordered this game through Amazon while I was in the US and once got it, the game was not working. I contacted the customer service and they directed me to Nintendo NL as I was traveling to Netherlands for summer. Then the Nintendo NL re-directed me to Nintendo US and then one of the Nintendo US customer service representatives said (very impolitely) that they can't do anything as I am not in US anymore and kicked me out of the chat. Well, I am in US again and the 3 month warranty is gone. Thank you Nintendo.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: christian armstrong
Title: Great game. Horrible control options.
Body: I love this game. It's a great game. It's easy to pick up and play for a few minutes or a few hours. It's great for new players and old. However something that I find very very VERY annoying is the touch screen controls. If you have big hands and are playing on a switch lite the touch screen controls are gonna be the destroyer of many rounds of playing. It's stupid cuz you cannot disable this setting either. You'll be mid drift or mid game and bam the game pauses. Other than this very minor detail it's an AMAZING GAME. It's just that this detail is very annoying to me personally.

Author: Nancie
Title: DEALING WITH NINTENDO WAS HORRIBLE, AMAZON PERFECT!
Body: Purchased the game as a gift.  My grandson opened the package and the case was empty - no game.  The amazon page referred me to Nintendo for issues.  I spent 1 hr with various staff and supervisors to no avail.  I was pretty much accused of trying to get a free game at least 3 times by 3 different people.  The last supervisor said he would e-mail me specific directions......never happened!  Found the amazon phone number, called not expecting much.  Well low and behold, within 3 minutes the whole issue was resolved and I got a refund.  Amazon was great to deal with...another reason to shop amazon.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: The Chosen One
Title: Fun game. Get the Nintendo online subscription to race against other people around the world.
Body: This game is so much fun! Unlike some other games, you don’t have to invest too much time to get enjoyment from this game. U can race a few games or a lot. This is my favorite switch game so far. There’s a lot of race courses and the game is deep enough to entertain you for a while.I highly recommend getting the online Nintendo subscription($20/year) to play against people from all around the world. It makes the game even more fun to play since there’s people out there with all sorts of driving skill levels and you never know just how a race will turn out.The price hasn’t gone down since the game came out, but for the amount of fun you can get from this game, It’s worth it.

Author: E.A.S.
Title: Mario Kart Is Back!
Body: For me, Mario Kart Double Dash has always been my favorite Mario Kart and cart racing game ever! I had it on the original Gamecube and put hundreds of hours in it. Well, move over Double Dash...I just bought Mario Kart 8 Deluxe today (7/5/20) and haven't put it down! I didn't even know I was playing for almost three hours!The graphics on this game blow me away. The Switch is actually a very powerful console and I'm pleased to see Mario Kart on it.From the vast array of characters to the crazy tracks, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, in my opinion, is better than Double Dash!Thank you, Nintendo, for bringing back such a nostalgic game to modern consoles.I haven't tried multiplayer but I'll update the review with my thoughts on the online portion of it.Seriously, buy this game. Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is the new championship (sorry Double Dash).
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: K. G.
Title: Amazing visuals and performance, but left me wanting additional tracks and characters
Body: Mario Kart 8 (Deluxe) has a lot of replay value, thanks to it’s many modes of gameplay, unlockables, online multiplayer and local multiplayer capabilities. This updated (Deluxe) version looks and performs better than ever before on the Nintendo Switch. No matter what controller setup you’re using, it’s going to feel very fluid and responsive.I’ve docked the Deluxe version of Mario Kart 8 one star, however. This is mainly due to the fact that there are actually no “real” new/additional racetracks or characters in this revamped offering on the Switch.I would have loved to have seen a couple of new cup races, even if the new racetracks were simply remasters of classic Super Mario Kart or Mario Kart 64 tracks. Anybody who played Mario Kart 8 on the Wii U has probably seen and raced every single track and cup that currently exists more times than they care to. So yes, a few additional cups or racetracks would have been a great addition.In addition to much needed additional content, it would’ve been great to finally offer a local and online 4-8 player Grand Prix mode. It’s been long awaited and let’s face it, it’s just time.I get that this could be a way to “cheat” against or exploit the shortcomings of the CPU characters and earn trophies “unfairly”. To alleviate this, they could have single player trophies and multiplayer trophies. Obtaining the single or 2-player trophies would be the only way to unlock the majority of secret characters, wheels, karts, etc., while winning the 4 to 8 player trophies would only earn coins or smaller, more trivial unlockables. All in all, I think this would be another exciting and super fun mode of gameplay to play and compete with friends.As I mentioned above, I feel there are some pretty serious character roster opportunities. Starting off, there are way too many slots for each variant of certain characters…Looking at you, Mario and Peach.Nothing’s quite as annoying than being in a race with Mario, Baby Mario, Tanooki Mario, Metal Mario...You get the idea.Why not make all of the character variants into character skins that all exist within just one character slot? It already works just fine for the Link, Yoshi, and the Shy Guy character slot variants. Each variant skin could still have it’s respective attributes, such as Tanooki Mario being a tad lighter or Metal Mario being heavier. Having so many variant slots currently makes the character selection screen look very jumbled and messy, and as I mentioned, who wants to play against a team of variants from just one character? I’d also love to see more random variations when it comes to CPU opponents’ kart kart/wheel choices. I think it goes without saying that everyone likes to see each CPU character in their standard karts and probably a bike, but a how about a few more variations to spice things up and make it feel a bit more randomized. To unlock everything you’ll be racing and seeing the same characters with the same kart combos A LOT.Lastly, my biggest beef is the actual character roster choices for this game. Namely the Inklings from Splatoon and the random selection of Animal Crossing characters. I get that these characters are technically part of the Nintendo family and belong to specific Nintendo console games, but another part of me can’t help feeling that these characters feel very out of place in the “Mario Universe“. I mean, if you’re going to add any Animal Crossing characters, why not Tom Nook, the Dodo, or K.K. Slider? I’m a huge Legend of Zelda fan, but at times, I even find myself questioning if Link really belongs or truly “fits” into the game all that well.Here are some choices I feel would have been a better” fit” or are more relevant additions to the Mario Kart 8 Deluxe roster...Mouser- Such an awesome and iconic Mario Bros. 2 throwback character. Why hasn’t he been in any Mario Kart game yet?SnifitNinjiPauline- Things are always more fun when Mario’s ex-girlfriend enters the mixKamek- Kamek was supposed to be in Mario Kart 64, but was swapped out in place of DK. Isn’t it about time we finally saw him as a playable character?Birdo- not a character I ever played as in the past, but still a relevant Mario character that just makes sense to include in any Mario Kart title.Blooper- another classic Mario baddie that really needs to be includedTryClyde- Another unique Mario Bros. 2 character worth inviting to the party.Hammer Brother- No explanation needed. Just put one in the game.Monty Mole- Just like the Hammer Brother, he’s already a playable Mario Party character. He’s been featured in several Mario Kart and non-Mario Kart titles as a non-playable character so why not include him now?The Giant Blue Penguin from Mario 64- I just want an excuse to see a giant penguin driving a go-kart, but technically it is a character in a Mario title.Duck Hunt Dog and Duck (complete with selectable color variants like Shy Guy and Yoshi)- They shared the same cartridge as Super Mario Bros. on NES- nuff said. It definitely makes more sense to me than including something as arbitrary and non-iconic as the Inklings.The Yellow Bunny from Mario 64- If you are going to continue to snub Pikachu and not include him in the Mario Kart 8 Deluxe roster, than please add this yellow rodent instead.Nabbit- Another great rabbit themed character worth having in the game.Dr. Mario, Fire Mario, Frog Mario, Raccoon Mario, Hammer Brother Mario, etc.WigglerBanjo/KazooieKing Bob-ombWingoDonkey Kong Jr.Diddy KongPichu/Pikachu/Raichu- the Pokémon could evolve after each lap or perhaps certain power-ups could temporarily evolve it. Maybe it just remains good ol’ Pikachu. Either way, a must have. Perhaps Pikachu gets a temporary Charizard outfit when he gets the fireball power-up. Maybe Pikachu de-evolves into Pichu when hit by lightning and evolves into Raichu when he gets the 3 mushroom boost or Bullet Bill power-up?Ash Ketchum- perhaps we see Pikachu and/or other Pokémon hanging on Ash’s shoulder or various animations of them popping out of his backpack or Pokéballs, doing cool Pokémon stuff. There is definitely potential for unique animations pertaining to Pikachu, Charmander, and Squirrtle when it comes to the lightening, fireball and shell attacks.Pac-Man- goes a bit faster than other characters as he collects coins, plus each coin gives him a slightly better speed boost than other characters for a very short amount of time. To balance this, his recovery time is the worst in the game if he gets hit with any weapon, and he gets knocked around very easily because of his extremely light weight class.Magikarp/Gyrados- begins as Magikarp with mediocre stats, but turns into Gyrados on the final lap with several stats maxed out like speed, weight, boost, and the best recovery time)Funky KongKing K. RoolKirbyMega ManMike Tyson- it makes a lot more sense than Animal Crossing and those dreaded Inkling characters. Technically Mario was in his game- he was the referee. Perfect tie-in😁
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Benjamin M. Weilert
Title: Advancing the Mario Kart series with anti-gravity, other franchise inclusion, and gorgeous visuals.
Body: Just like how Mario Kart 7 expanded on the core gameplay mechanic of the Mario Kart series by adding gliding and underwater features in its tracks, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe goes a step further and removes the confines of gravity from the franchise. This core change to the Mario Kart formula results in a lot of genuinely unique courses that couldn’t have been possible in previous games. To top everything off, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is presented in gorgeous high definition while also including all the downloadable content from the Wii U version at no additional cost.With a variety of new courses, as well as classic racetracks enhanced to the Switch’s advanced graphical capabilities, I was glad to finally see some representation in this franchise from characters outside the typical Mario franchise. Representative characters and courses from the Zelda, Animal Crossing, and Splatoon franchises felt like welcome additions and perhaps even the first steps toward making the Mario Kart franchise more in line with the celebration of video games that Super Smash Bros. Ultimate has become. Of course, the nostalgic tracks are pretty to look at but don’t hold any new secrets to discover in this iteration.Even if you need online access to play multiplayer across the internet, the Switch’s portability and a multitude of controller options make Mario Kart 8 Deluxe an easy game to bring with you anywhere you go and set up a multiplayer race on a moment’s notice. And while there are tons of characters, karts, wheels, and gliders to choose from, there isn’t much incentive to explore the other options in this game other than when a friend picks the character you usually play as and you’ll have to find someone new on the spur of the moment.Advancing the Mario Kart series with anti-gravity, other franchise inclusion, and gorgeous visuals, I give Mario Kart 8 Deluxe 4.0 stars out of 5.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Christopher Greffin
Title: Best Mario Kart Game Ever
Body: Mario Kart 8 Deluxe for the Nintendo Switch is certainly not a revolution for the mega-popular Nintendo series. Anyone who has played Mario Kart 8 on the Wii-U (you’ll be forgiven if you never bought that Nintendo system) will be on extremely familiar terrain (pun intended) with Deluxe. But with a few certain enhancements, and all of the extra DLC of MK8 available for free right from the start, this is the ultimate version of what is arguably the best—and certainly the most expansive and technically impressive—Mario Kart game ever. In my opinion it’s also the best online racing game I’ve ever played.In this game we have a bigger variety of tracks (a massive forty-eight in all), and racers (an expanded character roster from the already very diverse selection of Nintendo characters in MK8) than any previous entry in the series. Significantly, in MK8 Deluxe we have all the courses and racers unlocked from start (though you still must earn all the different carts, wheels, and parachutes—that allow you to alter the racer attributes—by completing the game’s modes and earning coins). Essentially the mechanics play like the Wii-U’s MK8, though one new upgrade here is the ability to hold two items at once, which in addition to making things a little more chaotic and fun adds a little bit of strategy to it. As in previous entries, going through the Grand Prix and time trials is a fun diversion (that is until you unlock the 200cc GP mode, which is very hard and really too fast for a Mario Kart game in my opinion, though some may enjoy such a challenge).But as solid as all the single-player modes of the game are, it’s the online multiplayer that’s where this game goes from a well-designed, fairly addictive racer, to being a frantic, super-fun, near masterpiece; from an enjoyable time to a potential obsession. This is not a first-time or even second-time feature in the series (which as early as 2005, with Mario Kart DS, had an online mode, and a good one which remember playing the hell out of), but on this game it comes with more polish, more variety, and yes, more fun, than any Mario Kart title of the past. In addition to everything all the game's modes come in glorious 1080P visuals, definitely improving on its predecessor, and has the crispest soundtrack in the series' history.If you’ve previously bought this game on the Wii-U—whose online play hasn’t been available for a while now so wouldn’t be much worth returning to—I would say it’s well worth shelling out for this version for fans of Mario Kart. And if you haven’t played MK7 then this game, that’s packed full of great content that will be fresh to you, with tons of replay value, is obviously one you must buy. One of the best racing games I have ever played.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

They kept me posted via email on the status of the repair. After all, I’m not sure if it was console of game issue.Console is not recognizing the game, giving us an error that game card could not be read. All other games are working just fine. I did try to update it - same results - game card could not be read.

Author: Nathan W.
Title: Solid game, great visuals, but they left the training wheels on
Body: This version of Mario Cart has great visuals and I liked all the new toys and power-ups(my last version was on the Wii). I also thought gliding off jumps was a fun new addition to the series. That being said, when I play this version of the game it just doesn't feel right. In older versions you could explore the edge of the map, and if you went the wrong way you ended up paying the price. This game feels like they left the training wheels on. When you get close to the edge of the track the game takes over control of your vehicle and points you back in the right direction. As it does this even before you leave the main track at times it leaves you feeling like you're not really in control.  For young kids this probably makes the game less frustrating, but for me I felt like I was bowling with the gutter guards on.  I wish this was an optional setting so my young boys could use it while I was free to succeed(or fail) on my own.Hopefully I don't have to wait for the next Nintendo system for a better version of this game.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Aria
Title: Made EXCLUSIVELY for children
Body: If you're looking for the fun and challenging courses you enjoyed in Double Dash, you won't find it here. The courses are diverse and visually stunning, which make them fun the first few times you try them. But there is NO challenge whatsoever. There are four different rainbow roads and I couldn't fall off of them when I TRIED to. The camera and course automatically moves you around obstacles so you could probably just hold down the A button and you'd still beat half the NPCs.On the other hand, if you want a game that your five year old and fifteen year old can play together, this is ideal. It levels the playing field across age ranges because you can't use strategy with your item throwing to screw over other players.Overall, if you are an older player or enjoyed the challenge in Gamecube-era games, you will be bored with this game after two or so playthroughs of each level.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Tachinator
Title: Wish there were more options...
Body: Bought it during the phone version release of this game, figured it might come with more maps to play besides the ones that this game already provides, was rather disappointed that there isn't much you can play. Liked that they have other options to play besides racing, like popping the balloons, and such. Maybe the online experience is much more different than the one you play locally.  It certainly was what garnered the attention of my younger cousins that wouldn't stop playing it despite its repetitiveness. Still recommend it for the sake of playing with multiple players when you have friends or family members over.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Javier Ferrer
Title: Deluxe indeed
Body: Mario Kart 8 Deluxe (I did not try the standard WiiU version) is the greatest Mario Kart since Double Dash. Perfect gameplay, great characters and balance, tracks, and a huge array of vehicles, wheels and gliders to choose from.If I were to take from it, however, would be due to the fact that all characters, GP levels and tracks are available from the get go. A little challenge and unlocking helps a long way. Also, with that many characters, some feel forgettable.Do not get me wrong - these are simply factors that I believe could provide an even better experience. Mario Kart at its finest. And we have probably played it for days, and the replay value is still there.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Ken
Title: Fun Game
Body: This game is fun, I enjoy playing it, but I think I enjoyed MK 7 more. This one does too much hand-holding. It doesn't allow me to fall off the map, and, overall, it seems to be fairly easy compared to version MK 7. I still recommend it. It's fun to play online and I like collecting coins to unlock the various karts. I just feel like the maps were more fun on MK 7. I miss some of them.

Author: Nathan
Title: Fun for everyone""
Body: It's really fun if you know what settings to mess with, but if you want to get three stars on all the grand prix races then be prepared to smash your switch into the wall. The normal grand prix races are terrible, because they mixed far too many different elements in at the same time, and the items cause the most skilled players to end up in 5th or 6th on a good day. The more powerful items are impossible to use without flying off the course, and the items you get when in the lead are pathetic. On multiple occasions I've been in first place for all three laps on the hardest difficulty with the hardest cpus, and three seconds before I cross the finish line I'm hit with a blue shell, red shell, bomb, you name it, and I end up with a little Nice Try! message. The items are a balancing method to make the game fun for everyone when really it just throws any of your skill out the window. Also the items do not work with the courses, especially on 150 or 200cc, because the courses are much more complex and difficult to maneuver, and most of the items give speed boosts, which are entirely too fast for the course. I've played Mario Kart for nearly ten years, and it's disappointing that I can't absolutely demolish my friends at it like any other Mario Kart. So if you're like me and want to hone your skills on the new courses, just do VS and turn off the items.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: J. Boyd Jr
Title: Fun for the family, but not the same as the past.
Body: I admit, I mainly bought this game for the nostalgia of Mario kart from n64. While the game does have that similar feeling it just isn't the same.I have three issues really with this game. The first is the scoring system. The second is the track limits. Third, the squid item. With that being said let me explain.Issue one, the scoring system.  In n64 Mario kart the scoring system was simply your position of finishing.  However, in this game it goes more than that. The bulk of your points are made from combat triggering items etc. The position you get just gives you a bonus in points. So what is my issue? Well, even if you finish in first, others playing with you may get a higher score due to them nailing people constantly with shells.Second issue, map limitations. One of the best things from older Mario kart games was when you knocked your opponent off the track. Mainly in corners. However, in this game you cannot be ran off the track. In fact, you cannot knock someone off the track and forced to be rescued except when you nail them with a shell while they are gliding in certain spots.Third issue, the squid ability/item. If you played previous Mario karts you probably remember the dredded moments when you take a turn only to have your screen blocked by black ink due to another player squidding you.  It was devastating in other versions. However in this version the ink is a joke. Enough of the screen is still visible that in most cases it doesn't effect you. However, another contributing aspect to it not being an issue is my issue mentioned above with not being able to drive off the edge.To sum up, the game will be a blast from the past and fun for the family. However it simply lost its racing aspect and not more focuses on the player interactions with each other.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Taylor Richards
Title: Babied version...autopilot
Body: I’ve always been a huge fan of mariokart and was super ready for this game to be released!!! I played on wii all the time. Anyways, I got the game and like most of the tracks, however, it’s very redundant and weak at the same time. I don’t like the fact that I don’t press my own gas, I can’t go in patches of grass or “cheese” because it blocks me from being able to go anywhere but on the track. Unlike the older versions. I felt babied throughout the races and how you can’t even fall off the side ledges of the tracks either!! It’s autopilot!!! It even turns me away from ramps half the time. I do love the animal crossing track though. I wish maple treeway was on it though too
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: NinjaDuck
Title: Good value - a few negatives
Body: These ladders create flexible options.  As you can see from my picture I actually used them on a trailer instead of a truck in order to make a kayak rack.Overall they are solid and sturdy.  As a few others have noted, the finish on several pieces came flawed.  The paint coat on them is easily scratched and they come pretty loosely packed in the box.The only other negative I would give them is that the 3/8 hex bolts that it comes with are only slightly larger than the holes in the ladder.  This does not give me a warm fuzzy feeling.  I would have preferred the heads to be slightly larger.  I will likely replace them with my own bolts.You will need your own 3/8 drill bit at 3/8 hex wrench to install.  The total install look my about 35 minutes including setup and drilling.

Author: Amazon Customer
Title: A great Mario Kart game, especially for two players
Body: At this point, the Mario Kart experience is something that most gamers are familiar with. The game is a ton of fun, requires a surprising amount of skill to succeed consistently, and packs a number of online features that are beyond the norm for Nintendo's library of games.The only thing I wish was different is the framerate for when more than two players are racing on split-screen; this is a game that is simply more fun in 60 fps, and it is capped at 30fps with three or more players. The hardware limitations are understandable, but I have a feeling that many players would have rather seen Nintendo explore a cut in resolution or graphics quality before cutting frames.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Crabby
Title: Don't buy
Body: It's fun I enjoyed beating the same level over and over all the way up to 150cc then I stopped.. So far I said I like it why the 1 star? Well it doesn't keep you playing everything is unlocked all plays and maps and modes.. So what's the point in grinding? Oh! That's right to unlock all car parts!!! Nah that's boring they pretty much do the same you have three different types not much really changes in the car, tires, shoot so once you got a couple unlocked you tend to stick to what you know. They also start you out in I'm handicap mode and all I can do is hit go. You can literally compete with friends doing nothing but pressing go and using items the only time it doesn't really work is when it's 200cc. I wish it had some grinding to unlock stuff to make me want to play. I just played it because I was bored and it was my only game at first. Now it's collecting dust.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Title: Fun party game

If you combine it with USB controllers or the Gamecube adapter you can use those controllers as well, it's a bit of a learning curve to relearn the controller, but that's how I also felt about relearning the feel of the joycons.

Body: This is a pretty solid and super fun game, you'll have blast, especially when playing couch multiplayer.I don't recommend more than three players playing on the same screen (unless you have a huge TV). I have a 49 inch TV and playing with more than three players makes the task of viewing the track a pain.The only problem with this game is when you're at first, after a really hard race, you're at the final lap, inches away from the finish line, then someone throws a red shell at you and you end up on 4th or worse... this will lead to a heart attack someday, pretty sure of it.

Author: James
Title: Disappointing
Body: This game is super disappointing compared to the gamecube version. The lack of user options and bad design makes it not worth buying. Examples include if you're ever in first or second place in a race, you'll never get any decent powerups. You'll generally be stuck with coins or bananas. You can't hit people to knock them off course and the jump feature is more like a miniature hop that doesn't matter at all. You can't selectwhich powerups are allowed in races or how many cpu ai's there are. This also goes for the battle mode. When playing balloons battle, you can't ram people to steal ballons. In fact, this game doesn't even have an in game settings page. This is a shameful production from Nintendo.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Spirit
Title: It's Mario kart 8 but for the switch with better features
Body: I would recommend it because of the online multiplayer online, but this time you have to pay a membership fee. Unlike Wii U players. The community is bigger on the Nintendo switch, so that means more online gaming matches. If you only care about single player content, and local multiplayer. Stick with the wii u version, because I would wait for a price drop. But Nintendo, won't really let that happen. I never owned Mario Kart 8 back when it released, so this is a necessary purchase for me, but I do feel for people who have already bought the game on the Wii U. I assure you though, that even if you buy the game a 2nd time. You will enjoy it.

Author: Bob
Title: Too Easy, too busy, too chaotic
Body: After playing Mario Kart Wii for years and years and enjoying the challenge of unlocking courses and characters and karts, I was looking forward to the new version of the game on the Nintendo Switch (we skipped the Wii U).  Kind of disappointed.  There's seemingly little challengs, and most everything (tracks, characters, courses) is available right off the bat.  You don't even have to push the 'gas pedal' anymore!  You can literally set the control down and finish the race by letting it drive itself, and you may even finish in a good position.  They tried too hard with the tracks to make them 'exciting'...instead some of them are just garish and chaotic and dizzying.  MORE MORE MORE doesn't always mean a better game, and that's what happened here.  It seems aimed at 5 year olds who always want to be a winner.  If nothing else they should have put in more controls over the game parameters to make it even a little more challenging like the old Wii version which was vastly superior.  If you want the numb sugar coated version, set it to that.  If you want a game with a little challenge, set it to old school rules.  If you loved Mario Kart Wii, this game will probably disappoint you and seem way to easy.  If you never played that version before, then this one will proably just fine for you.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Bryan
Title: This is a Wii-U Port
Body: This game, while an improvement, is quite literally a Wii-U port. Many will simply shove this off as Mario Kart itself is simply a continued resurrection of the same core gameplay. However, this game is notably a copy/paste of Mario Kart 8 on the Wii-U that they didn't even bother to change the name enough. They actually fixed the battle mode, fixed the item system during matches, and offered all DLC in lump-sum purchase. The game itself is a better rendition this time with HD quality within the game but a lot of things are still amiss. For example, the coin item is still in the game, item distribution by default in online is still wacky, kart mechanics are not traditional, etc. Overall, this game is what you'd expect from a true Mario Kart game but we shouldn't have had to buy a Switch just to get it, PERIOD.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Probably, but now I cannot return it as there is no way for me to hit return so my little brother who is 8 y.o. who was so excited is now super sad 👎🏻

Title: What is Mario Kart and is it fun?
Body: This review is for the folks that are unfamiliar with this product. The game is a non-realistic arcade racing game aimed at all ages. You can play in various modes against local split screen players, alone or online. The game has a great feature for inexperienced players that keeps them in the pack no matter how poorly you play. My 5 year old, his mom and I all play this game and it is a blast. You don't need to play online or even with others in order to enjoy.  It's just a joyful game.

Author: Common Sense Reviews
Title: Worst Mario Kart yet!
Body: This game was most disappointing out of all the Mario Kart series. I did not like the new version at all. The tracks, the music, the motion, the vehicles, the new power-ups, etc. The the timing on this game is completely redone from scratch and messes up what I've always known. It's much slower and doesn't respond half the time or more. The only saving grace of me keeping this was the Link free update and some remastered tracks. I highly don't recommend this one unless it's on a massive sale like how I got it for a little over $16.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Katie
Title: You will win, and the whole time you are... you will  be hit without any hope of getting fair items.
Body: Pro: Visually stunning... which, in 2018 is like saying air is awesome because you can breathe it.Cons/Facts: After all these years the gameplay is still weak. The only enjoyment to be had is if you have human friends to play with. Nintendo is incapable of providing a truly competitive CPU opponent, and so results to the usual cheap cheat tactics to cause you to lose. Double item slots are pointless when you will only recieve bananas, coins, and a rare shell if you are in first place against CPU. Literally across all the cups and every CC category, you will be bombarded with everything but the kitchen sink, and you will not recieve equal distro of items. This doesn't make the game more interesting or challenging... just annoying. I have had, on many occasions a half lap lead on CPU and their red shells seek you without inhibition. I threw a red shell at a CPU and it just missed, never turned to follow the CPU at all. I've still got triple star completions on every cup; it just isn't competitive. And again, totally pointless to have 2 item slots uou are in the lead your two items are most likely to be two coins... just pathetic. All the HD 3D environments cant fix weak game dynamics. They may as well just disable the controller anytime you start leading. What a waste of what could have been a great game. Wouldn't buy or recommend.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Svikelt
Title: Thrilling game to own for the Switch, and incredible to play locally
Body: This is a solid game to own on the switch, especially if you enjoy multiplayer hang outs, and for the Mario Kart franchise. I've been playing Mario Kart since the Nintendo 64, and I love the direction they went with this addition. The deluxe has all previously included and dlc characters and stages initially unlocked, which was a surprising amount of content, but I was slightly disappointed that there was not any progression to unlock them periodically. The game itself is very enjoyable and has a very high replayablity value. Playing on one joy-con and giving the other to a friend while playing outside was still loads of fun, but a little straining when you start to add 3 or 4 players to the tablet-sized screen. The graphics on the game were better than I had ever expected, especially while docked onto a 1080p TV. The price should be more reasonable and set to $50 at most, but overall a solid game.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Jevans01
Title: Not the greatest.
Body: This game is getting two stars from me because I think they could have done a lot better. The graphics are good and the character selection is great too, but that's about all it has going for it. I hate the actual racing, it requires zero skill and relies mainly on luck, and my biggest complaint is the way that items are distributed when racing. If you are 3rd place or better, just count on only getting coins or the occasional banana peel when getting an item box while the racers behind you load up on red shells and other devastating tools. It gets old very fast.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Kyle
Title: Great classic game with Awesome updates!!
Body: Seriously, who doesn't love mario cart. Ever since SNES I have loved this game. I like that it incorporates tracks from previous versions of the game. I especially LOVE the auto driving and steering features (you can disable these as well) so my 5 year old can play along without taking 26 minutes to finish a round... Sometimes she even places high in the rankings. This is a HUGE plus so thank you Nintendo. Lastly, this works great on the switch and I love that you can play so many different ways (I.e. consule screen, tv screen, multiplayer, motion controlled or regular button control). Really satisfied with this purchase.

Title: Fun game. Worth the rebuy if you like mario kart

If you didn't get mario kart 8 on the wii u,  I 100% recommend this game on the switch. On the other hand, if you already own the original version of this game, You really need to think for yourself about whether or not you are going to spend more time playing this game on the new console. For me the answer was yes, I will definitely spend hundreds of hours in this game, even though I have already played the wii U version

Author: Amazon Customer
Title: Only great for die hard battle mode fans.
Body: The game runs at a consistent 60 fps and looks beautiful. However Mario Kart 8 Deluxe doesn't offer anything new other than the 2 Splatoon characters, a couple of new karts and some new battle arenas and a 2 new battle modes being renegade mode and a capture the flag type of mode. Everything else just returning features, characters and abilities from older Mario Kart games. All in all unless if you're a die hard fan of battle mode such as myself or you don't already have a Wii U then there's no point in buying Mario Kart 8 twice.

Author: Brad Davidson
Title: It’s not without its glitches.
Body: This is a solid entry into the ninetendo switch offering list. However, there are a couple glitches. First, the pause menu came up unprompted on multiple occasions. This gave me the feeling that try as I may to beat the game, it was somewhat out of my hands. This brings me to the next point: “winning” the game is both too easy to do and too confusing to do so quickly. I spent about 10 hours  at 150cc Grand Prix mode. Up until hour 8 I phoned in my playing because I wasn’t sure I was involved in a challenge. Then, things started getting hard and I tried and won.  Anyway, this will be a hugely popular game, but it’s. It without its glitches.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Esteban
Title: One Of The Many Reasons Nintendo Hooked Me Back Into Video Games!
Body: One of the main reasons I purchased a Nintendo Switch aside from it's hybrid functionality is it's ease of playing with others and enjoying a variety of game experiences. Mario Kart offers such awesome experience that it's perfect for a married couple. My wife and I constantly play together when we can and truly have fun! The game itself is very colorful and runs smoothly no matter how you decide to play. It's easy to pick-up and play for newcomers or people that are not into video games yet it also offers challenging modes for veterans of the series.My only 2 gripes for the game itself is the character roster as well as unlockables or lack there of. The roster is comprised of some familiar faces but I wish there was more variety. It feels as if the koopa characters and other costume/baby variants of characters are fillers. It would have been nice to see characters from other franchises similar to super smash bros. That brings me into the second point which is the absence of unlockables. From the start all the characters and courses are available to you. The only items you are able to unlock are parts to customize your ride but I wish other forms of rewards were introduced such as more characters, courses, and an achievement list.Despite the two drawbacks of the game this is the definitive edition and it does not take away from the overall experience of having a great time playing with other people. It is easily a must own game the defines what the Nintendo Switch is all about!
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: jlo138
Title: Great game, needs more content though.
Body: It’s MK8 with the DLC added in that you had to purchase on the WiiU version. I’ve beaten the game rather quickly and unlocked everything besides the gold tires which require beating Nintendo Ghost time trials. 200cc is hard but I recommend that one first before 150cc mirror mode. Once you go from 200cc to 150cc, 150cc seems slow and so much easier by then.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Title: Dead on Arrival
Body: I don't want to rate this game too hard, mainly because I don't know how it plays since the cartridge was dead on arrival.I inserted the disk and it took over 3 minutes to load into the main menu. That time was way too long to be normal, so I deleted the software and reset my Switch. Once it was all booted back up, I put the cartridge in and was greeted with an error message. the game card could not be read. please remove and reinsert itI reinserted the game a few times, ensured everything was deleted (even the save data), rebooted a few times, and still got the message. I even tried it in my Wife's Switch. This card came broken.

Title: This is a great game! its a ton of fun to play ...
Body: This is a great game! its a ton of fun to play and made some nice improvements from the previous wii U version. you start off with all of the characters and difficulties unlocked but you have to earn the different cars, wheels and gliders by getting coins in each race. Each character has a unique place style with different weights, handling and traction, meaning that every character you play as, you need to change how you play it. The only issue with this game that I have is that too much is given to you in the beginning of the game and I wish I had to unlock the different characters like in previous games

Author: cwk
Title: Solid version
Body: I've played a lot of Mario Kart over the years and this is probably my second favorite behind the DS version. Starting with the Wii version they added gimmicks (like zero gravity and underwater) that don't really enhance the game in my view, and the courses got a little softer and less exciting (compare Bowser's Castle and Luigi's Mansion to the DS versions). The drifting mechanic is good and the countless kart / wheel combinations can make a big difference in handling. I find it's best to stick to one thing for a while. I like the coin system. The items are a bit too familiar to me at this point.I don't think Nintendo can do much more to improve on this game. Hopefully any follow-up will be a dramatic departure from the current formula.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Christian
Title: The Best version of Mario Kart yet!
Body: Okay so I already owned Mario Kart 8 for the Wii U. I was thinking should I really pay for a game I already own? I did and I am glad I did. All the extra courses I paid to download for the Wii U version are already included for the Deluxe version. Also, I really bought this to play with my kids (6 & 4) and the driver assistance controls are really great for younger players. There are three separate assistance controls. The first is a  guidance system to keep the Kart on the course. You'll know this is  enabled when you have  and antenna with a blinking light on the back of your kart.  The second is a steering option.  You can either use the joystick on the controller to steer the kart or  use the controller like a steering wheel.  And the third is an acceleration assistance.  You can use all or none of these options in any configuration you choose.  Also, if you have two pairs of joy con controllers up to four players can play.  I'm really happy with this purchase.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Ford Cates
Title: Great Kart Racer for Any Nintendo Fan
Body: A fantastic time all around. Whether you have friends to enjoy this game with you or not, there is plenty to do in Mario Kart 8 Deluxe. Everything that made the Wii U original game great is present here (as it is a boosted port) and the amount of content and gameplay is sure to have you coming back time and time again. Paired with the easy accessibility of the Switch and the simple controls, this game is a perfect fit for the casual or hardcore gamer, and potentially the most accessible and fun the Mario Kart series has ever been. My favorite feature personally has been the worldwide online races, where 12 people from all around the globe race against one another on tracks voted on by the players. Not to mention the various other modes to keep you entertained both offline and online. If you're looking for games to add to your Switch collection or picking one up for the first  time, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is an amazing game through and through.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Brandon
Title: How can it get better than this?
Body: The biggest thing I like about Mario Kart is the courses. Back when Mario Kart 8's downloadable content came out, I thought it was the best Mario Kart ever. I expected it not to hold that spot once the Switch came out, due to its lack of proper battle courses. And MAN was I right. Mario Kart 8 Deluxe marked the return of the actual battle mode and a few Switch exclusive content. I just can't imagine how good Mario Kart 9 will be after this masterpiece

Author: Merklynn
Title: Recommended, for now
Body: I am not really into racing games but mario kart is amazing fun, I love it.  Graphics are great, loads of stuff happening all over the place, races are fun, lots to do, loads of tracks/ vehicles/ game modes, easy to pick up and put down when you fancy ago, you don't have to spend hours in front of it but if you want to you will enjoy it.  It isn't a new game though, rather a re-release of the wii u version with improvements, not  a problem for me as I don't have one but if I already had it on that then I would think twice about buying as these games aren't cheap, though their price does fluctuate a lot, you can generally find them somewhere cheaper.  There are lots of multiplayer options, race online and all that which is great..... until September when Nintendo go the same way as the other console manufactures and start raking in a monthly fee which is annoying, specially as the longevity of this game is gonna be based on competition.  Lose a star for that (for now, maybe more when September hits).
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Amazon Customer
Title: Great game. We had it on the Wii U
Body: Great game.  We had it on the Wii U, and just recently purchased a switch.  I was hesitant to buy this version, since it didn't seem there is a huge difference from the Wii U version.  However, we have so much fun all playing together on the switch, I believe this game is a must have.  I don't feel bad at all about purchasing both.  I love having two sets of joy cons so my husband, myself, and our two kids can all get in on the fun!I did have a slight delivery issue-- my game was delivered to the wrong house.  However, amazon's customer service was top notch and refunded my money promptly, since we did run out and purchase it elsewhere when it did not arrive.  Still 5 stars in my book.

Author: Mad Max
Title: Maybe fun with multi players but utterly fails as a single ...
Body: Maybe fun with multi players but utterly fails as a single player experience. There really is little to accomplish. (Yes I don't give a carp that you MIGHT be able to unlock a gold Mario if you can somehow randomly win on the hardest setting.)You unlock new skins for your cart and that is about it. (and I am hard pressed to tell if any of them mean anything to the actual racing mechanics, most of the cars seem to be exactly the same speed and handling)I guess I am spoiled by games like Zelda where I am actually accomplishing something, but the racing also seems quite random, you can be in first and you just get hit with some random shell or lightning and boom, you finish 5th place.I give it an extra star just because the course are pretty cool. Guess this would be better at a much lower price for what it is.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Troy
Title: An insult to the original game.
Body: This game is truly terrible.  Its spits in the face of it's origins.  Skill is replaced with luck so the game is a roll of the dice.  You can powerslide around every corner perfectly and hit every jump boost but the way the power ups are distributed you'll end up getting clapped over and over again. Yes you can win the occasional online game but the feeling is shallow knowing you were mostly lucky. The tactics of holding onto a green shell or banana for defense is longer viable with the amount of ghost power ups used in race.  I wish they'd just make a remake of the original with updated graphics and additional courses with the same balance.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Nathaniel
Title: Do we really need blue shells, ink blots, and lightning to happen 3x in every race?
Body: The last Mario Kart game I played was on the N64. While it had the problem of the computer getting super human speed every time it was behind, it didn't detract from the races too much.Fast forward to 8 on the switch and the tracks remind me of F-Zero, which i think is pretty cool. I like the driving dynamics and how you have to use your brakes on 200cc to avoid hitting the walls, however, the use of items by the cpu characters gets really annoying. The blue shells, lightning, and ink blots occur almost in every lap. This becomes a nuisance after a while as the game seems to rely heavily on the use of items. In the N64 version, you were lucky if you got one of these gamechanger items per race. Also, getting a coin as an item is kinda lame.Conclusion: it's definitly fun but the item use may get annoying
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

The game is casual and simple enough for non gamers and young kids to pick up on, but complex enough for seasoned gamers to challenge themselves (and each other!) with. Author: Ryan Warsaw
Title: this is still a great title for the Nintendo Switch
Body: If you've played Mario Kart before, this is still a great title for the Nintendo Switch. The graphics have improved significantly over Mario Kart 7. All content is available from the beginning, which is great and terrible at the same time. The potential to unlock characters was a big part of the game for me, and I miss that from this release. You can unlock one character, Gold Mario which replaces Metal Mario but that is it.There's a wide variety of maps available, most of them are stunning and very fun to play. I'm disappointed with Battle mode, there is only a very small collection of maps available, and some are absolutely broken on certain mini-games like Renegade Round-Up where a match might last 19 seconds, even when playing against easy AI players just because they're so small and there aren't that many places to run around to.In Summary; Bring back the ability to unlock more than one character, and fix the major issues with your mini game offerings and it's perfect.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: JWK
Title: A Must Own Title for the Switch.  Stop Reading, Buy it NOW!
Body: This game is part of what I call the tri-force of Switch games that are required for ownership:1. Mario Odyssey2. Zelda Breath of the Wild3. Mario Kart 8 DeluxeSo far, out of the three games I have played, Mario Kart is the best.  Even as a remaster with DLC.  This game is perfectly optimized for the Switch. 60 FPS ALWAYS.  No dips.  When you go mobile, the game is extremely kind on the battery and last surprisingly long.Now lets get to the game:Tracks are a mix of old and new, and each track has unique hooks or features that don't make them seem stale.  Not to mention they are beautifully designed.  Plenty of characters to choose from, and an obscene amount of customization you can do to your go kart before the action begins.  Gameplay is fast, furious, and fun.The online mode is flawless in latency, and is always a joy to play.  What is the best is bringing someone who is playing in person with you online as well.This has been the only Mario Kart I have played since N64.  Just an amazing experience, please stop reading this and buy it now.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Title: Disappointing
Body: Mariokart 8 tries to do everything for you (steering, gas peddle). This is helpful out of the box for new players, but quickly makes the game  boring. Author: Tyler Jacobson
Title: A great game that's fun for all ages!
Body: Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is pretty much essential if your Nintendo Switch players are too young for Breath of the Wild or anything that's too sophisticated for young gamers.That's not to say it's overly simplistic, but it is a very easy game to pick up and just play.  You can choose among a slew of familiar characters, karts, and kart designs and accessories that you unlock as you play.  There are also a few updated versions of tracks from previous Mario Kart games.  The tracks are unique, varied, and provide just enough challenge.Speaking of challenge, you can start out racing at the 50cc engine class for beginners and younger players who are just starting out.  For more advanced players, with a higher skill level, the engine classes go up to 200cc, where the races are faster, more difficult, and require more drifting to be successful.There are also multi-player battle and vs modes so the whole gang can play.Overall just a fun game for all ages, and pretty much essential for Switch owners with kids.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Ryan Norred
Title: The Best Mario Kart Game Made Even Better!
Body: This is easily the best game in the series & I own every one all the way back to the very first game Super Mario Kart for the SNES. This is much like the Wii U MK8 but with a few more new characters, brand new battle modes & a bunch of minor tweaks that make it so much better than the original. The 2 DLC's from the original game are all unlocked which is a huge plus. It also looks better cause it runs at a full 1080p HD in docked mode while the Wii U version ran at 720p. I've played the Wii U version for the past 3 years & still love it just as much as when I first played it, so it was worth upgrading to this better version. The Mario Kart franchise has always been one of my favorite franchises & I still love playing all the games!

Author: Ginger Aille
Title: Great Game, TONS of content, endless family-friendly fun
Body: Santa dropped this game along with a new Nintendo Switch just 2 days ago. So far, this game is our #1 pick to play as a family.MK8D is far and away the best of Mario Kart games that I've played (and I've played most).  Many kart options, many drivers to choose, options for wheels, gliders, etc.  You can mix and match to find a combination that suits your driving style and personality.  There are 12 cups with 4 courses in each one (48 different tracks!), 5 different speeds (50cc, 100cc, 150cc, 150cc mirror, 200cc).  Many of the tracks are brand spanking new, which is awesome, but for fans of old school Mario Kart there are throwbacks to SNES, GameBoy Advance, N64, GameCube, and Wii tracks that give a sense of nostalgia, but they are refreshed for a new console with great graphics and gameplay.We haven't explored the battle modes or online play yet (just setting up new Nintendo Accts today), but we are looking forward to it!This is played with the individual joy cons so 2 can play with one set.  Either tilt steering or using the thumbstick.  We have also used controller wheels (sold separately, Amazon Basics) and *I* find them comfortable and easy to use, but others in my family prefer to hold the joycon on its own.One thing to note is that there is a new feature - Smart Steering - which helps users stay on the course instead of flying off into oblivion.  This is ON by default which is good for younger players and older players (like me) who tend to fly off the edge on courses like Rainbow Road, but it can be turned off easily in-game (during cart customization and again during the race).
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Jordan
Title: Mario Kart 8 Deluxe leaves the Wii U version in the dust.
Body: Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is an enhanced port of Mario Kart 8 , which was released for the not-so-great Wii U console. What's new in this version of Mario Kart 8 is the much-requested traditional Battle Mode. And Nintendo didn't stop there. We got not one-not two- but 5 different battle modes that do a splendid job in changing up the gameplay. The improved battle modes alone made me wan to purchase this game. If you want to know how each new battle mode works, then you'll have go to the official website, but I have to carry on with the review.The next new aspect of this deluxe version are 4  brand new racers, which is always a good thing. No problem here.Moving on, there is the inclusion of double-item boxes, which allow for two items to be held at the same time. If you weren't aware, the Wii U's Mario Kart 8 only allowed you to carry one item during a race, which meant after someone knocked your defensive item off or you get a lousy item such as a coin, then you were exposed to other racer's attacks. Now, we can have one item in the front slot for defense and the other in the second slot for a surprise attack. This addition was brilliant and makes gameplay all the better.We're not done yet, guys. This version also gives you EVERY BIT OF DLC that was costed money on Wii U. Now, it's free and it's included in this version as a part of the $60 package. This DLC includes 16 new racetracks and a few new racers (some of which are clones, but oh well).Lastly, small tweaks to gameplay were implemented in this Deluxe version. First, we have smart steering, which is PERFECT for beginners. Let's say little Suzie wants to play Mario Kart with her big brother Chad, just turn on smart steering and the game won't let her steer off course and fall to her demise. Next is a new drifting technique called the ultra mini turbo. This is more for advanced players but it's still a welcomed addition. All of the other additions are changes to gameplay balancing, so I won't mention them here.The verdict: So, you're probably wondering why I did nothing but praise this game, yet there's still one blank star on my rating. The reason is simple. MOST OF THESE FEATURES SHOULD'VE BEEN IN THE ORIGINAL GAME. Early adopters of the Wii U version, such as myself, were baffled as to why some of these features (that were standard in a Mario Kart game) were absent from the Wii U version. It's like they intentionally gave Wii U owners a watered-down game just to release this version. So, do I think this game is worth 60 bucks? Yes, if you've never bought a Wii U and are looking for a fun family game with TONS of replay value. But, If you already have the original Mario Kart 8...I really can't say. I bought this version because I needed some games to play on my new Switch. But, I can't imagine everyone else is ok with spending 60 more bucks on features you should've already been able to play PLUS DLC you've already bought. Just going to be honest, Nintendo did the Wii U owners dirty. Anyway, I hope my review helped you out. Happy gaming.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Willie G.R.
Title: A masterpiece revived with sharper graphics and a perfected vs mode.
Body: I will start by stating that, even tho the upgrades on graphics were minimal, they have made this already beautiful game into a masterpiece of vibrant colors and textures.  There are also the new items, characters, and the upgraded versus mode that truly make this game into what it should have truly been on WiiU.  That said, I still think Nintendo should have priced it at least 10 dollars less, as this game is still the same as the one on WiiU.  This is just my opinion in the matter, however, and I still think the game is worth purchasing, especially for those playing it for the first time.  Unlike the WiiU version, all race tracks and modes are already unlocked, and unlocking new vehicles has become easier, but trust me when I say you will still love this Mario Kart game to no ends.  One more note I would like to add is how much easier it is to play as 2 players, now that the Joy Cons come in pairs that can be used by two players at once.

Author: Logic
Title: Great cart racer but needs tweaking
Body: The game is fun, looks awesome, controls are awesome, its Mario Cart! My only complaint is the frequency of items during races. You can be the best cart racer in the world and still lose!!! One minute you're in 1st place perfectly drifting making Zero mistakes. Then bam you get hit by a blue shell, then another blue shell, then maybe a couple of red shells all in a row! You go from 1st, all the way to 5th even 10th all because of things out of your control. The better you race the worst items you get from randomized weapon boxes, meanwhile people in dead last are pumbling you with Shells and other items. I wish there was a game mode where Items weren't aloud aside from custom matches. The items make this game unplayable for me, I can't be competitive in a game that screws you for playing well. Seriously.......... what were they thinking with the items? I returned it I'll wait for the next Mario Cart that's more balanced because the weapon/item balancing in this game is atrocious and broken in my opinion. This isn't an exaggeration, go ahead and get it if you don't care about losing because of things that are out of your control. Frustrating, I really wanted to like it, I tried..................
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: CaptainK
Title: Love
Body: Mario Kart is always a classic that I love. Fell in love with the original Wii version and this one is much better. Some of the maps you'll recognize but many have new twists and there are new maps to race. I love the battle games as well. (Balloon Battle is my personal favorite) Switching to two or more player mode is easy. (When you first try two player, for some reason the settings will be all turned on such as the safer driving mode, so drifts don't work as well, and the players kart will always be hitting the gas, and in battle mode that's not convenient so make sure you turn those settings off). And online playing is a welcome addition. You can choose between regional and world. There isn't a 'Grand Prix' in the online racing, just one race at a time. And playing Battle online, there's just one round at a time, no 4 rounds and then a winner is decided. Also there's no picking which battle game you want to play, it just cycles through the five. At first I didn't like it but it forced me to get better at games I didn't really play often. In the online playing there is a personal point system. You start out with 1,000 points and depending how you rank each round, you can either earn or lose points. (Got down to 988 and back up to 1250). While the console comes with two controllers, I find myself considering buying another set because I don't like the feel of playing with one controller, as it's so small. Also I keep tilt controls off cause I find it makes me lose control. All in all, a main staple to my gaming life.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: chess & checkers
Title: Great if you don't own Mario Kart 8 on Wii U, otherwise not worth the price.
Body: Well, this game suffers from re-release syndrome in my opinion. There's simply not enough new stuff to make it significantly better than the Wii U version. No new tracks, a couple new characters, some improvement to visuals and a few Battle Mode innovations. The only game changer is the ability to carry two items, and by extension, double item boxes. The problem is that the game becomes even more chaotic, over-the-top chaotic in my opinion. I used to eat 0-1 Blue Shells every race in 8, rarely ever 2, but in Deluxe, be ready to consistently be on the receiving end of 2-3 Blue Shells and/or 2-3 bolts of Lightning every race. Oh, and Blue Shells now have a high trajectory, so they don't hit anyone except the leader, making them even less useful for the racer throwing it and being more annoying for the leader. The game punishes you even harder for leading, which makes the main flaw of the Mario Kart series more annoying. I'm sorry, but if the main changes in the game make it worse, you can't expect more than three stars.So is the game bad? No, not by a longshot. It's great fun for adults, kids, parties, nostalgia and more. However, if you own the Wii U version with the DLC and are on a budget (Switch games are really expensive), you can safely skip Mario Kart 8 Deluxe. If you only have 8 on Wii U without DLC, I would still recommend just buying the DLC. However, if you don't have the Wii U version, it's a great buy.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: T Leary
Title: Best Mario Kart game yet!
Body: This game is faster, fresher, and more fun than ever before! It's fine and fun for all ages (with a bit of practice for newcomers), especially due to its new-player-friendly functions.Pros1. The graphics are beautiful. Pay attention to the detail of the course itself and everything outside the course (especially Baby Park and Ribbon Road).2. The new Smart Steering function keeps players from driving off-course, so that's why it's so great for new players (no idea why they didn't think of this before).3. New Battle Modes make the game even more epic. I have hardly ever had fun with Mario Kart Battle Modes until now. There are new courses and new modes.4. the new characters add more color to the game, especially since Bowser Jr. is my favorite character.Cons1. There are no new racing courses, which aggravates me.2. It's not the best single-player game out there. Fortunately, you can play online. Coming across bad words in Mii names (since none can be used in comments) is rare.Tips: Use Smart Steering on 200 CC. It helps. A lot.Overall, this game is awesome for any family or racer. Thanks for reading!
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: chris
Title: Mario Kart done right. Tight controls
Body: Should you buy this game if you already have the wii u version? If you are a big fan and/or you play the switch on the go allot, I would recommend this game, otherwise the wii u version should suffice.I have been a fan of the Mario Kart series but the biggest issue I've always had was the rubberband AI and victory was based on the items you got. When I first played this on the Wii U I was amazed by the controls. This game is more skill based than the previous games. I love old Mario Kart for nostalgia, but they havent aged well. The effects of items like red and blue shells have been reduced and the players behind you do not have that rubberband AI, so the hard work you put in to stay in first place pays off. There is still some luck involved, but that is part of what makes this game fun. The battle mode in the deluxe version has improved greatly. I can spend hours online playing battle mode. If there are some things that I can say i do not like is the way they have control option set up. It is very easy to turn an option on in the pause menu that you didn't intend to turn on. Also there aren't many unlockables which makes time trials less of an incentive to play.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Jonathon Spencer
Title: It’s fun but should be a $40 game
Body: This review is coming from someone who has not played Mario Kart since the Nintendo 64 version was out so keep that in mind. With that being said I do believe it’s missing something. I love the gameplay for battle mode and the races are definitely fun and its awesome that they have expanded the carts and the characters you can play with so now you have way more options of racers and carts. That being said, I think they should have 4x the levels on the game. This is a $60 game and half of the tracks are just a regurgitated version of the previous games. The nostalgia is cool and all but I believe there should be all of the retro levels and a bunch of new ones included with this title. Also there are only 4 or 5 levels that you can play in battle mode. I love this game and its been a blast but I think you can play all there is to play in one day. Given the fact that Xbox and PlayStation are releasing their new games at the same cost, there should be way more bang for the buck on this game rather than just a nostalgia factor.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Dale  B.
Title: A worthy upgrade from Wii U's MK8
Body: If you like Mario Kart 8 for the Wii U, you'll probably want this Switch version too. It's pretty much the same game but with enough tweaks to make it a worthy buy.You'll notice the video and sound quality is improved. There are some new characters and vehicles like the inklings and the splat buggy.The big deal with this Switch version of MK8 is more dynamic gameplay  with double item boxes that can put you in the lead almost instantly if you're lucky.The 200cc tracks are slightly easier here than in Wii U's MK8 which is good because they'll come up as options when you play live. Mirror tracks also appear in live races here for the first time.If you win a live race you get to strut around with a big crown after the race.It's good to be the King!
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: B
Title: Did not like the last Mario Kart (Wii U) for one tiny ...
Body: Did not like the last Mario Kart (Wii U) for one tiny reason. You could not hold two f****** items. That has been a huge part of strategy in the last mario kart games. Constantly getting a coin in first only to have a red or green shell hit you gets annoying. This allows for having a defense as well as planning ahead on when to use your items. Makes the whole game more intense and strategic. The addition of the super boost from drifting is welcome although you barely can use it as it takes a lot of turning. The battle mode is also pretty cool addition. If I knew more people with the system i think it'd be more fun but I usually still stick to just plain racing. The worse part of the port, which is terrible on Nintendo's part, is the fact that they couldn't add a few more tracks. The tracks are WAY to short to begin with. would have been nice to have an additional minute or 2 of racing because it ends too fast. So that would have been nice. Also, they have to figure out this online voice chat. It's 2017and if a company worth a few billion dollars can't implement this then who knows.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Sara Elder
Title: Great game but not a sequel.
Body: Great game, but it's much like the first one. The differences incude: 60 fps and 1080p, three new battle modes, two new items, you can hold two items at the same time- which be helpful. You also get a few new cart items but nothing too big. Great game but might not be worth the upgrade if you have the first one. If you didn't get the Wii U version of this game it will be a great game for you. But if you did it might just be worth it for the new battle modes.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard

Author: Jimbob64
Title: Fun party game- grab a friend and go nuts!
Body: Purchased it yesterday for play with my girlfriend, since our existing plans fell through. She and I both used to play (different versions of) Mario Kart in the past but neither of us had picked up the game for a long time since.Like one would expect, we picked up the game and weren't very good at it in the beginning, though everything felt comfortable and familiar. As we played for the next few hours (which positively flew by), we brushed the rust off our skills and had just as much fun lapping the  CPUs in the various modes as we had laughing  at our own wipeouts earlier.Neither  of us had a problem with using a single  Joycon each, though I shouldn't like to think how using items or drifting would be  without the Joycon strappy things to give us proper shoulder buttons.Notes for new owners: Auto steering and auto accelerate (and tilt-to-steer) are on by default and the game doesn't tell you how to disable them unless you go looking. To turn these things off or on: Start a race, pause, and cleck the top corner/s of the screen, which show you which buttons toggle these features.Also, reviews who say there's practically nothing to unlock: That is only true of characters. Except Gold Mario (reskin of Metal, unlock by finishing all cups at 200cc), the whole roster is available from the start. All tracks seem to be available, and  that is actually more fun  for the two of us- we could race anywhere, from the start. Kart upgrades/options unlock every few races based on  how many coins you collect total, seemingly at random. There seems to be a satisfying amount to unlock in terms of parts, though I have yet to try much beyond Yoshi + standard everything, who plays exactly how I remember him as my best character.Not sure how much fun it'll be now that  she had  to fly home again, but if you have a second player (and preferably a TV), it's a blast.
Styles: Platform For Display: Nintendo Switch | Edition: Standard
